paper_title: Interfacial facet engineering on the Schottky barrier between plasmonic Au and TiO2 in boosting the photocatalytic CO2 reduction under ultraviolet and visible light irradiation
source: The Au-TiO 2 samples were obtained by depositing Au nanoparticles on TiO 2 nanocrystals through a ligand-exchange method 50.
context: In a typical synthesis of TiO 2 octahedra 48, potassium titanate precursor (0.01 g, preparation method in Supplementary data) and hexamethylenetetramine (0.70 g, 5 mmol) were sequentially dispersed in the mixed solvent of ethanol and water (6 mL, v/v 1:2) under ultrasonic treatment.The resulting solution was then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and was kept at 200 C for 48 h.TiO 2 truncated octahedra were synthesized under the same experimental conditions as TiO 2 octahedra except the use of water (6 mL) instead of ethanol/water mixture.In a typical synthesis of TiO 2 sheets 49, 10 mL of tetrabutyl titanate (Ti(OBu) 4 ) and 2.5 mL of hydrofluoric acid solution were mixed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and then kept at 200 C for 24 h.After being cooled to room temperature, the as-obtained white powder was separated by centrifugation and washed with ethanol and water for several times, and finally dried at 45 C for 24 h. The Au-TiO 2 samples were obtained by depositing Au nanoparticles on TiO 2 nanocrystals through a ligand-exchange method 50.In brief, TiO 2 samples (10 mg) were dispersed in 5 mL of an aqueous solution containing 150 L 3-mercaptopropionic acid (MPA) and 150 L NH 3 H 2 O (28) through sonication.Then 400 L of aqueous dispersion of Au nanoparticles (preparation method in Supplementary data, 1.64 mg mL -1 ) was added under sonication for 10 min.The as-obtained mixture was kept static for precipitation, centrifuged and washed with water for several times, and finally annealed at 200 C to remove the MPA and increase the contact between Au and TiO 2 . 3.0 mg products were dispersed in a mixture of 15 L ethanol and L Nafion, which were then uniformly spin-dropped onto at a 1 cm cm indium tin oxide (ITO)-coated glass by a spin coater.Subsequently, the ITO-coated glasses were heated at 80 C in a vacuum oven for 1 h.The photoelectrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI 760E electrochemical station (Shanghai Chenhua, China) in ambient conditions under irradiation of a 300 W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE 300D/300DUV, Beijing Perfectlight, China).UV and visible lights were used as the illumination source, which were realized in the presence of a shortwave-pass 420 nm cutoff filter (320 420 nm) and a long-wavepass 420 nm cutoff filter (420 780 nm), and the power densities were measured to be 33 and 100 mW cm -2 , respectively.A threeelectrode cell was used to perform the electrochemical measurements with the ITO-coated glass, Ag/AgCl electrode and Pt foil used as the working electrode, reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively.The three electrodes were inserted in a quartz cell filled with 0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 electrolyte.The photocurrent density was measured under chopped light irradiation (light on/off cycles: 30 s) at a bias potential of 0.4 V versus Ag/AgCl for 600 s under both visible and UV light irradiation.Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed in the 10 -1 to 10 5 Hz frequency range with an AC voltage amplitude of mV at an applied potential of 0.1 V versus Ag/AgCl under UV light irradiation.Transient open-circuit voltage decay (OCVD) was measured for a total of 800 s under visible light irradiation, and the light was switched on and off after 100 and 400 s from the start, respectively. The photocatalytic experiments were carried out in a 100 mL reactor purchased from Beijing Perfectlight Company (China) under atmospheric pressure at ambient temperature (298 K), in which 10 mg of the photocatalysts were dispersed in 1 mL H 2 O at the bottom.Prior to the test, the reactor loaded with the catalyst was first purged with high purity CO 2 for 20 min.Then the light-irradiation experiment was performed by using a 300-W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE 300D/300DUV, Beijing Perfectlight, China) with UV and visible light as the illumination source, respectively.The UV and visible light was realized in the presence of a short-wave-pass 420 nm cutoff filter (320 420 nm) and a longwave-pass 420 nm cutoff filter (420 780 nm), and the power densities of which were measured to be 33 and 100 mW cm -2 , respectively.After the photocatalytic reaction for 4 h, the products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC-2014, Shimadzu) with Ar as the carrier gas.The amount of CH 4 was measured by using a flame ionization detector (FID).CO was converted to CH 4 using a methanation reactor and then analyzed using the FID.The O 2 was also detected using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD).During the stability test, the photocatalyst with the best catalytic activity was collected after each run and then reused for the reduction of CO 2 .Isotope-labeling experiments were performed using 13 CO 2 , and the products were analyzed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (7890B/5977A, Agilent).

paper_title: Interfacial facet engineering on the Schottky barrier between plasmonic Au and TiO2 in boosting the photocatalytic CO2 reduction under ultraviolet and visible light irradiation
source: In summary, we demonstrate the rational interface design of Au-TiO 2 heterostructures to boost the photocatalytic performance in CO 2 reduction based on the choice of suitable facets of TiO 2 nanocrystals in depositing Au.
context: In summary, we demonstrate the rational interface design of Au-TiO 2 heterostructures to boost the photocatalytic performance in CO 2 reduction based on the choice of suitable facets of TiO 2 nanocrystals in depositing Au.It is found the Au-TiO 2 (O) outperforms Au-TiO 2 (T) and Au-TiO 2 (S) in CO and CH 4 production under both UV and visible light irradiation owing to the formation of only Au/TiO 2 (1 0 1) interfaces rather than Au/TiO 2 (0 0 1) ones.Our investigation uncovers that the height of Schottky barrier created at the Au/TiO 2 (1 0 1) interface is smaller than that at the Au/TiO 2 (0 0 1) interface owing to the lower Fermi level of TiO 2 (1 0 1) facet compared to that of TiO 2 (0 0 1).The decrease of the Schottky barrier height not only enhances the transfer of CB electrons from TiO 2 to Au cocatalysts upon UV excitation of TiO 2 , but also facilitates the migration of hot electrons from plasmonic Au to TiO 2 when exposed to visible light.The smooth interfacial electron transfer promotes the separation of the photogenerated charge carriers, contributing to more efficient CO 2 photoreduction.This work highlights the importance of interfacial facet design during the fabrication of metal-semiconductor hybrid photocatalysts. paper_title: Interfacial facet engineering on the Schottky barrier between plasmonic Au and TiO2 in boosting the photocatalytic CO2 reduction under ultraviolet and visible light irradiation
source: In both circumstances, rational design of metal/ semiconductor interface is highly desirable to smooth the migration of electrons and promote the separation of carriers.
context: Hybrid photocatalytic nanostructures composed of plasmonic metal and wide-band-gap semiconductor components have been widely developed, in which metal not only acts as a cocatalyst to trap the photogenerated electrons from semiconductor for improved charge separation and provide highly active sites for accelerated reaction kinetics, but also serves as a light-harvesting antennae to extend the light absorption region based on the injection of plasmonic hot electrons into the semiconductor.In both circumstances, rational design of metal/ semiconductor interface is highly desirable to smooth the migration of electrons and promote the separation of carriers.Herein, based on the deposition of Au on TiO 2 nanocrystals with different exposed facets, it is found that the formation of Au/TiO 2 (1 0 1) interface lowers the height of Schottky barrier in comparison with Au/ TiO 2 (0 0 1) interface, enhancing the transfer of conduction band (CB) electrons from TiO 2 to Au cocatalysts under ultraviolet light irradiation and promoting the hot electron injection from plasmonic Au into the CB of TiO 2 with the excitation of Au by visible light.The more efficient interfacial charge transfer and separation enable more electrons participating in the conversion of CO 2 to CO and CH 4 .As a result, at both excitation wavelengths, the Au-TiO 2 sample with exclusive Au/TiO 2 (1 0 1) interfaces significantly ameliorates the photocatalytic activities in CO and CH 4 production compared to other samples containing Au/TiO 2 (0 0 1) interfaces.The interfacial facet engineered Schottky barrier may open a new window to rationally designing metal-semiconductor hybrid structures for photocatalysis.

paper_title: Interfacial facet engineering on the Schottky barrier between plasmonic Au and TiO2 in boosting the photocatalytic CO2 reduction under ultraviolet and visible light irradiation
source: enhancing the transfer of conduction band (CB) electrons from TiO 2 to Au cocatalysts under ultraviolet light irradiation and promoting the hot electron injection from plasmonic Au into the CB of TiO 2 with the excitation of Au by visible light.
context: Hybrid photocatalytic nanostructures composed of plasmonic metal and wide-band-gap semiconductor components have been widely developed, in which metal not only acts as a cocatalyst to trap the photogenerated electrons from semiconductor for improved charge separation and provide highly active sites for accelerated reaction kinetics, but also serves as a light-harvesting antennae to extend the light absorption region based on the injection of plasmonic hot electrons into the semiconductor.In both circumstances, rational design of metal/ semiconductor interface is highly desirable to smooth the migration of electrons and promote the separation of carriers.Herein, based on the deposition of Au on TiO 2 nanocrystals with different exposed facets, it is found that the formation of Au/TiO 2 (1 0 1) interface lowers the height of Schottky barrier in comparison with Au/ TiO 2 (0 0 1) interface, enhancing the transfer of conduction band (CB) electrons from TiO 2 to Au cocatalysts under ultraviolet light irradiation and promoting the hot electron injection from plasmonic Au into the CB of TiO 2 with the excitation of Au by visible light.The more efficient interfacial charge transfer and separation enable more electrons participating in the conversion of CO 2 to CO and CH 4 .As a result, at both excitation wavelengths, the Au-TiO 2 sample with exclusive Au/TiO 2 (1 0 1) interfaces significantly ameliorates the photocatalytic activities in CO and CH 4 production compared to other samples containing Au/TiO 2 (0 0 1) interfaces.The interfacial facet engineered Schottky barrier may open a new window to rationally designing metal-semiconductor hybrid structures for photocatalysis.

paper_title: Interfacial facet engineering on the Schottky barrier between plasmonic Au and TiO2 in boosting the photocatalytic CO2 reduction under ultraviolet and visible light irradiation
source: It is found the Au-TiO 2 (O) outperforms Au-TiO 2 (T) and Au-TiO 2 (S) in CO and CH 4 production under both UV and visible light irradiation owing to the formation of only Au/TiO 2 (1 0 1) interfaces rather than Au/TiO 2 (0 0 1) ones.
context: In summary, we demonstrate the rational interface design of Au-TiO 2 heterostructures to boost the photocatalytic performance in CO 2 reduction based on the choice of suitable facets of TiO 2 nanocrystals in depositing Au.It is found the Au-TiO 2 (O) outperforms Au-TiO 2 (T) and Au-TiO 2 (S) in CO and CH 4 production under both UV and visible light irradiation owing to the formation of only Au/TiO 2 (1 0 1) interfaces rather than Au/TiO 2 (0 0 1) ones.Our investigation uncovers that the height of Schottky barrier created at the Au/TiO 2 (1 0 1) interface is smaller than that at the Au/TiO 2 (0 0 1) interface owing to the lower Fermi level of TiO 2 (1 0 1) facet compared to that of TiO 2 (0 0 1).The decrease of the Schottky barrier height not only enhances the transfer of CB electrons from TiO 2 to Au cocatalysts upon UV excitation of TiO 2 , but also facilitates the migration of hot electrons from plasmonic Au to TiO 2 when exposed to visible light.The smooth interfacial electron transfer promotes the separation of the photogenerated charge carriers, contributing to more efficient CO 2 photoreduction.This work highlights the importance of interfacial facet design during the fabrication of metal-semiconductor hybrid photocatalysts. paper_title: Interfacial facet engineering on the Schottky barrier between plasmonic Au and TiO2 in boosting the photocatalytic CO2 reduction under ultraviolet and visible light irradiation
source: The photoelectrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI 760E electrochemical station (Shanghai Chenhua, China) in ambient conditions under irradiation of a 300 W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE 300D/300DUV, Beijing Perfectlight, China).
context: In a typical synthesis of TiO 2 octahedra 48, potassium titanate precursor (0.01 g, preparation method in Supplementary data) and hexamethylenetetramine (0.70 g, 5 mmol) were sequentially dispersed in the mixed solvent of ethanol and water (6 mL, v/v 1:2) under ultrasonic treatment.The resulting solution was then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and was kept at 200 C for 48 h.TiO 2 truncated octahedra were synthesized under the same experimental conditions as TiO 2 octahedra except the use of water (6 mL) instead of ethanol/water mixture.In a typical synthesis of TiO 2 sheets 49, 10 mL of tetrabutyl titanate (Ti(OBu) 4 ) and 2.5 mL of hydrofluoric acid solution were mixed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and then kept at 200 C for 24 h.After being cooled to room temperature, the as-obtained white powder was separated by centrifugation and washed with ethanol and water for several times, and finally dried at 45 C for 24 h. The Au-TiO 2 samples were obtained by depositing Au nanoparticles on TiO 2 nanocrystals through a ligand-exchange method 50.In brief, TiO 2 samples (10 mg) were dispersed in 5 mL of an aqueous solution containing 150 L 3-mercaptopropionic acid (MPA) and 150 L NH 3 H 2 O (28) through sonication.Then 400 L of aqueous dispersion of Au nanoparticles (preparation method in Supplementary data, 1.64 mg mL -1 ) was added under sonication for 10 min.The as-obtained mixture was kept static for precipitation, centrifuged and washed with water for several times, and finally annealed at 200 C to remove the MPA and increase the contact between Au and TiO 2 . 3.0 mg products were dispersed in a mixture of 15 L ethanol and L Nafion, which were then uniformly spin-dropped onto at a 1 cm cm indium tin oxide (ITO)-coated glass by a spin coater.Subsequently, the ITO-coated glasses were heated at 80 C in a vacuum oven for 1 h.The photoelectrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI 760E electrochemical station (Shanghai Chenhua, China) in ambient conditions under irradiation of a 300 W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE 300D/300DUV, Beijing Perfectlight, China).UV and visible lights were used as the illumination source, which were realized in the presence of a shortwave-pass 420 nm cutoff filter (320 420 nm) and a long-wavepass 420 nm cutoff filter (420 780 nm), and the power densities were measured to be 33 and 100 mW cm -2 , respectively.A threeelectrode cell was used to perform the electrochemical measurements with the ITO-coated glass, Ag/AgCl electrode and Pt foil used as the working electrode, reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively.The three electrodes were inserted in a quartz cell filled with 0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 electrolyte.The photocurrent density was measured under chopped light irradiation (light on/off cycles: 30 s) at a bias potential of 0.4 V versus Ag/AgCl for 600 s under both visible and UV light irradiation.Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed in the 10 -1 to 10 5 Hz frequency range with an AC voltage amplitude of mV at an applied potential of 0.1 V versus Ag/AgCl under UV light irradiation.Transient open-circuit voltage decay (OCVD) was measured for a total of 800 s under visible light irradiation, and the light was switched on and off after 100 and 400 s from the start, respectively. The photocatalytic experiments were carried out in a 100 mL reactor purchased from Beijing Perfectlight Company (China) under atmospheric pressure at ambient temperature (298 K), in which 10 mg of the photocatalysts were dispersed in 1 mL H 2 O at the bottom.Prior to the test, the reactor loaded with the catalyst was first purged with high purity CO 2 for 20 min.Then the light-irradiation experiment was performed by using a 300-W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE 300D/300DUV, Beijing Perfectlight, China) with UV and visible light as the illumination source, respectively.The UV and visible light was realized in the presence of a short-wave-pass 420 nm cutoff filter (320 420 nm) and a longwave-pass 420 nm cutoff filter (420 780 nm), and the power densities of which were measured to be 33 and 100 mW cm -2 , respectively.After the photocatalytic reaction for 4 h, the products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC-2014, Shimadzu) with Ar as the carrier gas.The amount of CH 4 was measured by using a flame ionization detector (FID).CO was converted to CH 4 using a methanation reactor and then analyzed using the FID.The O 2 was also detected using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD).During the stability test, the photocatalyst with the best catalytic activity was collected after each run and then reused for the reduction of CO 2 .Isotope-labeling experiments were performed using 13 CO 2 , and the products were analyzed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (7890B/5977A, Agilent).
